Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Mechanics, Sensing, and Control in Multi-Fin Swimming - Biological Strategies for Systems with Distributed Sensing, Actuation, and Tunable Plant Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The scientific goal of this project is to understand biological strategies used in the sensory-based control of kinematics and plant properties in sophisticated locomotor systems. This research uses the bluegill sunfish (Lepomis macrochirus) as a model for investigating how biological systems integrate distributed sensing, neural based control, and tunable mechanics to achieve remarkable levels of performance. The sunfish is selected because it is representative of a large class of fish that use multiple fins and multiple swimming gaits, and that integrate a great deal of sensory information, to swim with extraordinary agility across a wide range of fluidic conditions. This work will be accomplished using a combination of behavioral studies of the swimming sunfish; mathematical investigations of the mechanics and control of multi-fin swimming; and experimental studies with biorobotic models of the sunfish locomotor, sensory, and control systems.

This research program will lead to new perspectives for the design of high performance systems based on biology, and will provide insight into principles common to neurobiology, behavioral biology, and engineering. These new perspectives will help us design systems that exhibit characteristics which are hallmarks of animal systems - autonomy, agility, robustness, efficiency - but which have been difficult to achieve using traditional engineering approaches. Example systems include autonomous swimming vehicles that navigate oceans and explore cluttered harbors, and high performance aircraft that modulate their structure so that an aircraft automatically tunes itself to different flight regimes. Partnerships with the New Jersey Academy of Aquatic Sciences and with the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University will provide an avenue for translating research discoveries into educational modules for middle- and high-school students. This will introduce teachers and students in the Camden and Philadelphia public school districts to engineering and math through the lens of biological systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this work, we have developed an understanding of how sensing, control, and mechanics are integrated in fin-based systems to produce forces for swimming. Biorobotic devices have also been used as the foundation of an undergraduate design course and for use by Philadelphia based museums to teach engineering to K-12 students through the lens of biological systems.

This work has revealed that propulsion forces are very sensitive to the phase relations between the body and the dorsal, anal and caudal fins. This is due to the way in which a downstream fin engages with the wake that is shed from the body and upstream fins. Propulsive forces can be nearly doubled when the phasing is correct, relative to the forces generated when the phasing is tuned improperly. The level of force and the phase relations that create the highest levels of force are further affected by the stiffness of the fins and the frequency at which the fins are flapped. By tuning the flapping frequency to the resonance frequency of the fins, forces and efficiency can be improved. Our experimental work with naturally swimming fish suggests that this occurs in biological fish, too.  Fish seem to hold the stiffness of a fin relatively constant over a range of swimming speeds, and then will actively increase or decrease the stiffness of a fin when the fish desires to swim significantly faster or slower. The phasing and flapping frequency of fins can be tuned to the mechanical properties of fins by using sensors embedded in the fins that measure fin curvature and the dynamic interaction of the fins with the surrounding water. This information can be used in a control scheme called a central pattern generator to drive the motions of the fins and to change phasing relations when it is desired for the engineered system to swim faster or to produce forces for turns.

Through partnerships with the Academy of Natural Sciences, the Franklin Institute, and the Center for Aquatic Sciences our research team has been able to engage with middle- and high-school students from across Philadelphia and Camden, NJ. By using biorobotic devices that were developed by undergraduate students, the research team was able to introduce K-12 students to concepts that were common to biology and engineering and illustrate that the tools of  engineering are accessible and helpful for answering interesting questions. The collaboration between the museums and the undergraduate course will remain a permanent part of the undergraduate curriculum.
